5. The Chief of the Air Staff said that he had made some enquiries, but was not yet able to confirm that more than five German aircraft had been interned as Soesterberg.
The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs referred to telegram No. 208 from the Hague. It was certain that a number of German aircraft were interned, but the Dutch were being very secretive about the whole matter. They were also being very secretive as to violations of Dutch air neutrality by German aircraft. For example, on the 10th November, six aircraft, believed to be German, had flown over Amsterdam and had been shot at by anti-aircraft guns, but no reports had appeared in the Press.
The War Cabinet took note of this statement.
Poland. Formation and equipment of Polish forces.
6. The Secretary of State for War reported that he had received a letter from the Polish Prime Minister containing proposals for the formation of an armoured division, and up to 7 infantry divisions, of which the majority would be formed in France but one or two in Canada. He had asked that we should provided certain items of equipment and also hutted accommodation and training staff for personnel which might come to this country to train before proceeding to Canada.
The War Cabinet was informed that the Polish Prime Minister had also interviewed the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, the Secretary of State for Air and the Minister for Co-ordination of Defence, and that the question of the utilisation of Polish personnel had been discussed at these meetings. In the discussion which ensued on the policy to be adopted in this connection, the following were the principal points which emerged:-
(i) The Poles were very anxious that their forces should retain their identity and not be incorporated in French or British units. They wished to conclude a formal agreement with us on this matter.
(ii) They would like to be represented on the Supreme War Council, although they apparently would not press this point. They were very anxious, however, to have a representative with the Anglo-French Permanent Military Representatives in London.
(iii) There would be great political value in reconstituting a Polish Army which would fight alongside the British and French forces and thereby keep in being the entity of the Polish nation as one of the original Allies.
(iv) The formation of Polish Divisions in Canada which had been proposed by the Polish Prime Minister, would be of importance from the point of view of opinion in the United States. But the Canadian Government was understood to feel some doubts about this proposal.
(v) The Polish Naval units which had escaped and joined the British Navy were of a high quality, and it was probable that Polish troops would fight equally well. Officers and N.C.O.s were lacking, but there were some 80,000 Poles now in France.
(vi) The policy of the French was to provide the Poles with manufacturing facilities in France with which they could make the necessary equipment for their forces, using polish labour. They proposed to equip the Polish formations on a somewhat lower scale of armament than in the corresponding French formations.

The Chancellor of the Exchequer gave the War Cabinet a brief account of the discussions which he had had with M. Reynaudduring the previous two days. The main object of his discussions had been to ensure closer touch between the British and FrenchTreasuries. There were a number of financial matters on which he hoped to persuade the French to take an equal share with us. Hethought that it was more likely that we should reach a settlement by an approach on broad grounds, rather than by a number of individual approaches on particular subjects.The Chancellor of the Exchequer said that M. Reynaud hadbeen aggrieved at the extent to which we had found it necessary to restrict imports of French goods. The goods concerned were mostlyarticles of luxury, and we therefore had little choice in the matter.He was hopeful, however, that he might be able to reach anagreement with the French whereby, if we agreed to some relaxation in regard to the importation of French goods into this country, theFrench would be willing to provide franc exchange for the payments made to our troops in France.After a short discussion, the War Cabinet Took note of the statement by the Chancellor of theExchequer.Richmond Terrace, S.W.1,November 15, 1939.
